metadata.titleEn: Data set of trace elements, sulfur and lead isotopes in KEKETALE lead zinc deposit
metadata.description: The influence of deformation and metamorphism of post volcanic massive sulfide on the trace elements and sulfur lead isotopic composition of sulfide is still unclear. The Keketale VMS Pb Zn (- Ag) deposit provides an opportunity to solve the above problems; Five ore samples from No.7 and No.9 orebodies were crushed and screened for lead isotope analysis of bulk minerals, 17 polished thick sulfide samples were used for in-situ trace element and sulfur lead isotope analysis, 66 trace element determination points were analyzed, and 25 sulfur isotope points were determined; A total of 18 point pairs of different minerals were selected for lead isotope analysis, and LA-ICP-MS method was used
metadata.instructions:
File name: KEKETALE lead-zinc deposit trace elements, sulfur lead isotope data set, the name of the file is "KEKETALE trasl. Xlsl", in which KEKETALE represents KEKETALE lead-zinc deposit, trasl trace elements, sulfur lead isotope
Data reading mode: all ASCII files in the data set can be directly opened by Excel

authorList.unitEn: Sun Yat-sen University, School of Earth Sciences and Engineering

literatureList.titleEn: race elemental and sulfur-lead isotopic variations in metamorphosed volcanogenic massive sulfide (VMS) mineralization systems: An example from the Keketale Pb-Zn(-Ag) deposit, NW China
literatureList.referenceEn: Yu, P.P., Zheng, Y., Wang, C.M. (2020). Trace elemental and sulfur-lead isotopic variations in metamorphosed volcanogenic massive sulfide (VMS) mineralization systems: An example from the Keketale Pb-Zn(-Ag) deposit, NW China. Ore Geology Reviews,125, 103685.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of how a dataset on trace elements and sulfur-lead isotopes can be used to study the effects of deformation and metamorphism on VMS lead-zinc(-Ag) deposits?
Example.Answer: A dataset collected from the Keketale VMS lead-zinc(-Ag) deposit includes trace element and sulfur-lead isotope analyses, which can be used to study the effects of deformation and metamorphism. The data involves crushing and sieving ore samples for bulk lead isotope analysis and using LA-ICP-MS for in-situ trace element and sulfur-lead isotope analysis on polished thick sections. This approach provides insights into how these geological processes influence the composition of sulfide minerals.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection methods used for analyzing trace elements and lead-sulfur isotopes in VMS lead-zinc(-Ag) mineral deposits?
Feature Specification.Answer: crushing and sieving ore samples, polished thick section sulfide samples, LA-ICP-MS, 66 measurement points for trace elements, 25 points for sulfur isotopes, 18 points for lead isotope analysis

Quantification.Question: How many microelement measurement points are included in a dataset related to sulfide minerals in the context of VMS lead-zinc deposits?

Interpretation.Question: What can the use of LA-ICP-MS for in-situ microelement and lead isotope analysis tell us about the effectiveness of this method in understanding deformation and metamorphic effects on sulfide mineral composition?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of LA-ICP-MS for in-situ microelement and lead isotope analysis provides detailed information on the elemental and isotopic composition of sulfide minerals. This allows researchers to effectively assess the impact of deformation and metamorphic processes on the mineral composition by analyzing the variations in microelement and isotope data collected from sulfide samples.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in accurately analyzing trace elements and isotope compositions in VMS lead-zinc deposits, and how do these challenges affect the data collection methods?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The deformation and metamorphism of volcanic massive sulfide deposits can complicate the trace element and sulfur-lead isotope compositions, making it challenging to obtain accurate analyses. These challenges necessitate the use of sophisticated data collection methods such as LA-ICP-MS for in-situ microanalysis, which can help isolate and accurately measure the isotopic and trace element variations across different mineral samples.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects on the understanding of sulfide mineral deformation and metamorphism when utilizing data collection methods that analyze microelements and sulfur-lead isotopes in lead-zinc(-Ag) deposits?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The potential effects include a deeper insight into how deformation and metamorphism impact the composition of microelements and sulfur-lead isotopes, which could provide opportunities to resolve uncertainties regarding post-volcanic massive sulfide genesis.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of analyzing the microelement and sulfur-lead isotope composition in sulfide minerals from VMS lead-zinc deposits using LA-ICP-MS?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to understand the impact of post-volcanic deformation and metamorphism on the microelement and sulfur-lead isotope composition of sulfide minerals in the Keketale VMS lead-zinc(-Ag) deposit, providing insights into the geological processes affecting these minerals.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps involved in using LA-ICP-MS for analyzing microelements and lead isotopes in sulfide minerals from a dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural steps involve crushing and sieving ore samples for bulk lead isotope analysis, preparing polished thick sections of sulfide samples for in-situ analysis, performing microelement determination at 66 points on sulfide minerals, and conducting lead isotope analysis at 18 points using LA-ICP-MS.
